title: sync creates public listable bucket with --s3-acl=public-read
body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
The standard way of hosting a static website on S3 is to make the bucket private and upload files with public-read permissions.

For this, I'm using rclone sync with `--s3-acl=public-read`. This works well.

My problem is, that if the sync command creates the bucket (silently), then it becomes a public listable bucket when using `--s3-acl=public-read` for the synced files.

There are two concepts here, which are somehow mixed with rclone sync.
- bucket's policy
- the different files' policy within the bucket.

I believe a sync command's --s3-acl=public-read should only apply to the uploaded files.
I personally think that sync shouldn't create buckets, but that's probably a historical decision in rclone and will never change for backward compatibility.

I don't know what would be the best solution now, but at least printing a line about "Creating public readable bucket: {bucketname}" would be very important, in my opinion.


#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
```
rclone v1.45
- os/arch: darwin/amd64
- go version: go1.11.2
```


#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)
macOS 10.14.2


####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)
AWS S3


#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
`rclone sync --s3-acl=public-read`
